utterances: And when I find something that's on the ground, even if it's a tiny thing, even if it's a broken arrowhead, it is so much more powerful there than it is on a shelf or in a display case.
And, you know, I'm not saying we need to get rid of all the artifacts we've gathered.
I'm just looking at it going, we don't need to take everything.
We can leave some stuff out there, and there's not that much left.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Me too.
I walked thousands and thousands of miles across deserts and mountains, and I know.
I've seen the holes.
I've seen where diggers have been.
And I know that there is a lot missing, and I know that these last pieces that are remaining are rare, and I don't want them moving.
Author Craig Childs.
His new book is ""Finders Keepers: A Tale of Archeological Plunder and Obsession.
Craig Childs, thanks so much for taking the time to talk with us.
Oh, you're welcome, Audie.
Like lots of American cities, Milwaukee is trying to develop strong trade ties with China.
It doesn't have glamour, high finance or a large Chinese population on its side, though.
So the city is trying to market to China through the popularity of a rookie forward from China on the NBA Milwaukee Bucks.
Wisconsin Public Radio's Chuck Quirmbach reports.
Cash rich Chinese investors are putting more dollars into the U.S., but not really into Midwestern cities like Milwaukee.

As he arrived in town for a recent game that some called the Chinese basketball Super Bowl, local computer programmer Rick Xiang said his adopted city of 600,000 people is not well-known back in his native China.
Because you know, I have to tell people I live near Chicago, so people know, oh, okay, yeah, the Chicago area.
But actually, now I can tell people, say I live in Milwaukee.
The big game featured the hometown Bucks and their rookie forward, Yi Jianlian, against the Houston Rockets and their Chinese star, Yao Ming.
The event drew Chinese media and was televised back to an estimated 200 million viewers in China.
When the starting lineups were introduced, Yi - as he's known - got a huge ovation.
(Soundbite of cheering)
Leaders of the Milwaukee Association of Commerce were happy so many people in China heard more about their city.
At one of several receptions for business leaders and diplomats, China's Chicago-based Consul General Ping Wong admitted Yi has sparked his interest in Wisconsin.
I have been to Milwaukee, I think this is the fourth time since Yi came.
The marketing pitch for Chinese investment dollars includes more than basketball.
The Milwaukee area has become one of about 20 U.S.
regions to get up an immigration investment zone called an EB-5.
Local trade consultant Bob Kraft says foreign investors who promise to create at least ten full-time jobs and meet other criteria can accelerate the process of becoming a U.S.
citizen.
That's unique in the United States in that it is in an urban area in the Midwest and we're the only one, and we're close to Chicago.

Michael Waxman studies international trade and sees nothing wrong with trying to bring Chinese investment dollars to a smaller manufacturing center like Milwaukee that has lost thousands of jobs to China and other foreign countries.
But Waxman, who teaches at Marquette University, says there has to be a sustained commitment.
We're not going to compete with New York and Los Angeles, but we are going to have a substantial place if we invest in that longer-term picture.
And some cities in the United States have done that and are reaping some rewards, and some haven't and they are still well behind.
And there may be one other challenge to using athletes to help spark international trade.
Yi Jianlian played poorly in the game against Yao Ming, and Yi hurt his shoulder.
He's still expected to take part in a game for top rookies at the NBA All-Star festivities in New Orleans.
But the Milwaukee business community is courting on Yi to stay healthy, play well and keep helping Wisconsin make good impressions back in China.
For NPR News, I'm Chuck Kraumbauc in Milwaukee.
A controversial energy bill would require vehicles on U.S.
roads to raise the gas mileage standard to 35-miles per galleon by the year 2020.
NPR's Jack Speer reports.
Fuel economy standards have been around since the Arab oil embargo of 1973.
The standards, known as CAFE for Corporate Average Fuel Economy, were supposed to reduce U.S.
dependence on foreign oil.
But over the years, vehicles have gotten bigger and heavier and hope for economies never materialized.
In a manufacturing summit in Washington last week, North Dakota Democrat Byron Dorgan warned the heads of GM, Ford and Chrysler that higher fuel efficiency standards are coming.
I have previously voted against CAFE standards, but I just want you to know, I think the issue is over.
I think you've lost that issue.
The auto execs concede they will probably have to live with some increase, but GM Chairman Rick Wagoner says Congress needs to look at other alternatives.
Things like bio-fuels, encouragement of advanced technologies; these are the kind of things that can actually get us to the point of reducing the reliance on oil and oil imports.
But environmental groups are skeptical.
They say automakers have dragged their feet when it comes to upping fuel efficiency.
It's not clear whether a new mileage standard will actually emerge.
An alternative proposal has been floated by two Democratic senators from Michigan.
Jack Speer, NPR News, Washington.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Michele Norris.
He is responsible for roughly 40,000 employees and oversees everything from the U.S.
census to National Weather Service forecasts.
Oh, and there's a little matter of promoting American business and trade in the midst of a vicious global financial downturn.
Commerce Secretary Gary Locke was sworn in last week, and he has his work cut out for him.
I asked him if the White House ouster of the General Motors CEO sends a dangerous message to other U.S.
businesses.

When we last spoke, the island was deserted essentially, that residents or some residents were coming back on the weekends to maybe collect some belongings and to clean up their properties but that nobody was living there.
What's it like now?
The scene was much more complicated and chaotic than the original video had suggested.
Zimmerman didn't think the teenagers were blameless.
She spotted some of them making tomahawk chops.
But she understood that her initial reaction had been hasty.
That's when she was hit with a dilemma.
I was afraid to tell a few people, initially, that I had changed my mind, which is crazy.
Like, why can't you just say, you know, I think I was wrong about this?
But I knew some people would be upset because it's as though you're giving your enemy ammunition, and you can't ever admit that maybe the other side has a point.
When Zimmerman wrote an essay for The Atlantic admitting she had been wrong, right-wing commentators seized on it.
My essay was weaponized against liberals, against progressives.
And I - you know, it made me uncomfortable to see that.
Like, oh, gosh, did I make a mistake here?
My brother-in-law called my husband to say Rush Limbaugh just mentioned your wife's name on the air.
And I thought, oh, gosh, what have I done?
(SOUNDBITE OF RADIO SHOW, ""THE RUSH LIMBAUGH SHOW"")

One of the drive-by media outlets that really roasted these kids has published a piece - ""I Failed The Covington Catholic Test: Next Time There's A Viral Story, I'll Wait For More Facts To Emerge"" - Julie Irwin Zimmerman.
She was one of the early pilers on and she is begging forgiveness.
She failed the test.
I know the temptation, but why isn't there even a moment's pause when anything from social media becomes source material in drive-by media?
If liberals like Zimmerman had initially jumped to conclusions about how the video showed that conservatives were racist, Limbaugh and other conservatives used Zimmerman's essay to tar all liberals.
The first blast of misstatements and errors triggered the next blast with its own misstatements and errors.
Psychologist Molly Crockett at Yale says these cycles of outrage feed on one another and can produce fatigue and disengagement among audiences.
If the volume on everything is turned to 11, how do you separate signal from noise?
It's just constant.
There's a constant drip feed of outrage online, and it makes it hard to know where to focus your efforts.
The massive amount of outrage on social, broadcast and print media also come with another downside.
Psychologist William Brady says it's pushing Americans deeper and deeper into their own echo chambers.
The type of people giving you the shares and the likes, it tends to be people who share your political views.
That's because even as outrage is effective at capturing attention, its audience is mostly people who share the same beliefs.
The people who disagree are listening to rants in their own echo chambers.
Brady and Van Bavel find that messages presented with less outrage are more likely to spark conversations with opponents.
Those are the people, after all, whose views we want to change.
Shankar Vedantam, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF CAVES OF STEEL'S ""TRANSVERSE"")
From NPR News, this is News & Notes.
I'm Tony Cox.
